instruction: In a large bowl, combine yogurt, ginger paste, garlic paste, salt, cardamom powder, and nutmeg-mace powder.
title: Marinate the Mutton - Step 1

transcript_segments.text: As-salaam-alaikum, today I’m sharing with you the recipe to make Awadhi Biryani. You’ve probably made many types of biryani before—spicy, full of masalas—but Awadhi Biryani is completely different.
To make this biryani, first take 5 cups (1 kg) of long-grain, high-quality basmati rice. Wash the rice well 3–4 times and then soak it for half an hour.
In a bowl, take 3 tablespoons of garlic and add half a cup of water. Mix it well and strain it. Use a strainer to extract the juice from the garlic.
We don’t need the garlic paste—just press it thoroughly to extract the juice. Set this aside. Now take 1 kg of chicken, which I’ve already cleaned and prepped.
Add salt to taste. Then add 1 cup of thick, fresh yogurt. Add the garlic water we just extracted. Then add 2 teaspoons of red chili powder or Kashmiri chili powder.

instruction: Add half of the fried onions (birista) to the yogurt mixture and mix well.
title: Marinate the Mutton - Step 2

transcript_segments.text: Add salt to taste. Then add 1 cup of thick, fresh yogurt. Add the garlic water we just extracted. Then add 2 teaspoons of red chili powder or Kashmiri chili powder.
Awadhi Biryani is all about aroma. It’s built on fragrance, not heavy spices. That’s why I’m adding 2 tablespoons of kewra water. Also add 3 tablespoons of ginger paste.
As you can see, very few spices are used here—that’s the specialty. Now add some whole spices: 7–8 small green cardamoms, 1 large black cardamom, 1/4 piece of nutmeg, 2 cloves.

instruction: Add the mutton pieces and coat them thoroughly with the marinade. Cover and refrigerate for at least 4 hours, preferably overnight.
title: Marinate the Mutton - Step 3

transcript_segments.text: Now set this marinade aside for 15–20 minutes. Meanwhile, boil water for the rice—about 4 to 5 liters. Add 2-inch cinnamon sticks, 4–5 small cardamoms, and 7–8 cloves.

instruction: Soak saffron strands in warm milk for 10–15 minutes to release color and aroma.
title: Prepare Saffron Milk - Step 1

transcript_segments.text: Now set this marinade aside for 15–20 minutes. Meanwhile, boil water for the rice—about 4 to 5 liters. Add 2-inch cinnamon sticks, 4–5 small cardamoms, and 7–8 cloves.

instruction: Add rose water and kewra water to the saffron milk. Mix gently and set aside.
title: Prepare Saffron Milk - Step 2

transcript_segments.text: Now set this marinade aside for 15–20 minutes. Meanwhile, boil water for the rice—about 4 to 5 liters. Add 2-inch cinnamon sticks, 4–5 small cardamoms, and 7–8 cloves.

instruction: Rinse basmati rice thoroughly until the water runs clear. Soak in water for 30 minutes, then drain.

instruction: In a large vessel, bring ample water to a boil. Add bay leaves, cinnamon stick, green cardamoms, cloves, star anise, black cumin seeds, and salt.

instruction: Add the soaked rice to the boiling water and cook until the grains are about 70% done—firm with a slight bite.
title: Boil the Rice - Step 3

transcript_segments.text: Add oil and 3 tablespoons of salt. Adding oil prevents the rice from becoming sticky or breaking. Cover the pot so it comes to a boil faster.

instruction: Drain the rice immediately to prevent overcooking and spread it out to cool slightly.
title: Boil the Rice - Step 4

title: Layering the Biryani - Step 1

instruction: Spread the marinated mutton evenly on the bottom as the first layer.
title: Layering the Biryani - Step 2

transcript_segments.text: Add oil and 3 tablespoons of salt. Adding oil prevents the rice from becoming sticky or breaking. Cover the pot so it comes to a boil faster.

instruction: Add a layer of the partially cooked rice over the mutton.
title: Layering the Biryani - Step 3

transcript_segments.text: Add oil and 3 tablespoons of salt. Adding oil prevents the rice from becoming sticky or breaking. Cover the pot so it comes to a boil faster.
Cook the rice only 50–60%. Do not overcook. Even 50% is okay. Don’t go to 70–80%. The rest of the cooking will happen with the gravy later.
The remaining cooking will happen with the chicken gravy. I’ve heated about 1 cup (250 ml) of oil—biryani uses a generous amount of oil.
Fry the onions until perfectly golden. Once they are golden, add the marinated chicken and fry it on high heat for 8–10 minutes.
Now to cook the chicken, add half a cup of water, cover the pot, and cook for 10–12 minutes. The rest will cook later with the rice.
I’ve cooked this on low heat for 10–12 minutes. The chicken is about 50–60% done—semi-cooked. At this point, turn off the heat and add 3–4 cups of milk along with a few strands of saffron.
If you don’t have saffron, you can use food color—red or orange. Add 1/2 teaspoon cardamom powder and 1 tablespoon more of kewra or rose water.
Now separate the chicken pieces from the gravy (yakhni). Set the chicken aside. On top of the yakhni, you’ll see oil (called "tari")—separate and keep it.
Don’t waste anything. Keep the yakhni because it will provide the final taste and flavor of the biryani. Only discard the excess impurities floating on top.
Now layer the separated chicken pieces at the bottom of the pot. Pour all the yakhni over the chicken. I’ve also taken half a cup of warm milk here.

instruction: Sprinkle the remaining fried onions, chopped mint, and coriander leaves on top.
title: Layering the Biryani - Step 4

transcript_segments.text: Now layer the separated chicken pieces at the bottom of the pot. Pour all the yakhni over the chicken. I’ve also taken half a cup of warm milk here.

instruction: Drizzle the prepared saffron milk evenly over the top rice layer.
title: Layering the Biryani - Step 5

transcript_segments.text: Pour the saffron milk mixture over the rice. If you don’t have saffron, use food coloring. Add the oil we separated (rogan) on top—this gives a nice finish and flavor.

instruction: Cover the pot with a tight-fitting lid or aluminum foil to trap steam.

transcript_segments.text: Now seal the pot—either with dough or foil. I don’t prefer sealing with dough as it can be risky, but you can if you like. Cover it tightly and prepare for dum (slow steam cooking).

instruction: Seal the edges with kneaded dough if using a traditional lid, to ensure no steam escapes.

title: Seal and Cook on Dum - Step 3

instruction: Turn off the heat and let the biryani rest undisturbed for 10–15 minutes to allow the flavors to settle.
title: Rest and Serve - Step 1

transcript_segments.text: Let the biryani cook on dum for about 25 minutes on low heat. Don’t open the lid in between. Keep it fully covered so the biryani steams perfectly. Your Awadhi biryani is now ready with beautiful aroma.
How did your biryani turn out? Mine turned out great—everyone loved it, Mashallah. You’ve probably made many spicy biryanis—try this fragrant Awadhi biryani once; you’ll love it.
